title: How to Shoot Stock Photography

steps.headline: Develop your skill in photography.
steps.description: While you may have gotten some lucky shots in the past, earning a living with stock photography takes some skill along with a bit of business sense.

steps.headline: Shoot what you know.
steps.description: Don't just shoot at what you think everyone wants. If you have a strength, or interest, use it.

steps.headline: Keep the shots simple.
steps.description: Don't put too much in any one picture. A 'busy' picture will not usually sell.

steps.headline: Take more than one shot and angle of any picture.
steps.description: Stock photography, is quite often, a numbers game. If you take a LOT of pictures, (providing their quality is good), something will eventually sell.

steps.headline: Try to strive for being different without over doing it.
steps.description: That individuality may be what sells or what catches people's eyes.

steps.headline: Develop a comprehensive work flow.
steps.description: Different things work for different people. Find what works for you and stick with it.

steps.headline: Know where your photographs are.
steps.description: This is part of your work flow. Processing the images as soon as you are done taking them and cataloging and/or tagging them will help you substantially.

steps.headline: Find stock photo companies.
steps.description: There are several of them. Check them out to see if they suit your purpose. It is also a good idea to ask your photographic compatriots about experiences they have had.

steps.headline: Educate yourself about the business side of it.
steps.description: If you go into it totally unaware, you will find yourself on the losing end.
